I enjoyed the new characters and the puzzles. As usual there's a minigame to make some money, there's a lot of travel back-and-forth, but generally it's easy enough to figure out the next step. Whenever I got stuck is because i hadn't thoroughly examined a place. 
The only weird bits were some of the character interactions, especially between Nancy and her dad, and some of the flashbacks made me wonder why adults were acting like children. Nancy and her dad definitely could use some therapy by the sound of things... Woudl recommend, it took me 7 hours to finish, you can judge if you want to pay full price for that or not. review: Good entry in the series. Nancy is lured to Scotland with a promise of information about her mother's death years earlier. When she gets there, she ends up trying to sort out a terrorist plot.  Good puzzles, some fun characters, and maybe one or two sentimental moments.  It doesn't nail the sense of "Scotland" the way some entries capture their locations (I don't count a single food stand with haggis as truly capturing life in Glasgow) but the mystery itself is very suspenseful and the unfolding backstory of Nancy's mother gives a certain extra depth to the story.  I wouldn't suggest this as the first Nancy Drew game to play, if you've never played one before. But with more than 30 games in the series, if you were only going to try five, make this one of them.

review:
i've had about 14 years of history with this series, which makes this one feel so much more special than it would if it were my first ND game. honestly? play a few others first (try the highest rated ones), then alibi in ashes, and THEN this one. it's still a good standalone game, but it's a GREAT instalment in an ongoing series. being familiar with the characters and world makes the story so much stronger.

as for the puzzles and story advancement, they're fun. i hated the one with the grid of letters and the glass panels tho lol. i like that you can opt in to "helping" the bad guys in exchange for more info. this game is genuinely tense and exciting in terms of pacing and anticipation. 

i rate it 9/10, only because there are a few critical hotspots that are hard to see and i would've been stuck for a lot longer if not for having accidentally moused over them, like a few locks/keypads hidden in the dark for example. sooooo frustrating! need better visibility. everything else is fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077093512', 'num_games_owned': 207, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1688092460}
review:
I'm playing my way through all of the ND games, and I suspect most people reading this review are too, regardless of reviews! But here are my thoughts anyway.

I have complex thoughts on this one. there were some things that were done so extremely well, and others that really could have been improved upon. starting with the good - this game adds so much depth to nancy's character, as well as her relationships with her dad, boyfriend, and mother of course. yes, we get to learn more about nancy's mother, but i think it's more important to get to see how nancy reacts to the knowledge she gains throughout the game. at the end, onions were definitely being chopped, i don't think another ND game has made me cry! the resolutions that nancy comes to regarding her mother's death and her own grief were really meaningful, and the VA's voice acting was especially excellent in this title.

regarding improvements...i really felt like they could have made better use of the location. it's scotland, and it feels like you get to see precious few scraps of locations that are definitively scotland - everywhere else, you wouldn't be able to tell where in the world it was taking place. there are several questions/observations raised by nancy about the situation that never get answered, and not in a wistful wondering way - in a genuine, plot hole sort of way. i loved the characters with the exception of the antagonist, i felt as if he could've been developed more and given more of a motive than 'lonely and sad' lol. 

that being said, i did enjoy the spy theme/gadgets of this game and it has a good mark in my book overall!!

review:
Nancy drew a silent spy in short is a love letter to all the fans of previous Nancy drew game players. With subtle nods to past games, plot lines that heavily focus on your past friends and a mystery about Nancy's lost mother. I think this game is truly one of HER interactive best. It's simple but also intense, has the right amount of mystery with the right amount of moments to leave you excited for more. 

To be honest the game made me cry several times, this feels like almost a send off to Nancy drew as a whole. Even though there was more games after it, this one felt like a final love letter. One thing I would argue is this game isn't welcoming to a random newcomer. If someone who hasn't played a single Nancy drew game picked this up I worry quite a lot would be missed.But if you're okay missing all the little references I'd recommend this highly. If you feel you're getting stuck the game will give you mini hints. But most puzzles do have easy ways of solving (if you're on amature). 

I really say give this one a shot if you've only played a handful of ND games. Heck give it a shot if you haven't and you love a good mystery/puzzle game.

review:
One of the best of the newer Nancy Drew games. The puzzles were a good difficulty - not so hard that it's frustrating, not so easy that it's boring - but the hints for solving a lot of them were buried in an overload of information. Often the keys to puzzles were in theory readily available but the game threw so much information at me I had difficulty sorting through it and remembering what info I'd been given. 

The plot too is a little complicated and convoluted so that I found it hard to sum up in a single sentence. However, the story is very action packed, especially for a Nancy game! 

One other difficulty I encountered was knowing what to do - this game, unlike all the other Nancy games that I've played, doesn't give the player the option to call one of Nancy's friends for a hint in Junior Detective mode, which made it even more difficult and confusing. Those hints often help in pointing me in the right direction or enable me to see something that I might have missed! 

Lastly, the mini games in Nancy adventures are very hit or miss - fortunately, the cookie decorating mini game was definitely a hit for me! (And made me wish I could find a job where I could earn $10 for every cookie I decorated in real life). There was a nice lack of painstaking chores and other characters' reliance on Nancy to do their jobs for them in this game too, which I appreciated. 

Though it isn't perfect, The Silent Spy is still one of the better Nancy Drew games and I can definitely see myself replaying it sometime in the future!

review:
Overall, I'd give this one a 7.5/10! I liked the story and the puzzles were a good level of difficulty, perhaps it was on the medium side. Some of the characters were great, some were alright. The setting of this game was a good one as well, however there weren't that many places to explore. I'm glad that the "chore" type stuff in this one was super minimal - barely there at all. I also liked that most of the resources you needed were with you most of the time. 

One of the weaker points to this one was that there was a lot of repetition in the conversations with the characters. I think Nancy asked the same questions like 10 times. But because I liked most of the characters enough, it was not unbearable, and you can skip through them. It also felt like a relatively short game compared to some others. 

For reference, my favorites in the series are Blue Moon, Royal Tower and Ghost of Thornton. My least favorite is Shadow Ranch (too many chores and annoying characters lol). I think the ND games are very subjective, and the setting is usually what makes the most difference to me personally. If you like European setting/spy stuff you'll probably enjoy this one.

review:
THIS IS MY FAVORITE NANCY DREW GAME:

- Fun money-earning thing (you make elaborate cookies)
- Souvenirs to buy
- Variety of puzzles, many of them logic or spatial-relationship based
- Tons of different locations to explore
- Nothing super taxing on your motor skills (I hate QTEs because I physically have problems doing them)
- Very modern, interesting story based on espionage (so lots of cool gadgets to use)
- The interface is sleek and tidy-looking (not so with the older ND games)
- You can skip ahead in the dialogue when people are taking too long to get to the point
- Game flow was mostly intuitive, though I did consult the walkthrough several times (however that's normal for me in these games)

I don't have much bad to say here. I'm not your typical Nancy Drew fan; I like the mystery bits fine, but I'm mostly here for the errand running, chores, and tasks. I live for checking off that little pop-up list! So if you're into more of the classic, "secret passage in a haunted house" type game, this might not be for you. Even so, if you're an ND games fan and you run out of titles to play, get this on a sale. At the very least you may enjoy the puzzles. :)

review:
If you've played Her Interactive Nancy Drew games before, you'll love this one. I grew up playing the very old Nancy Drew games such as Ghost Dogs from Moon Lake and this one is much more updated and has smooth mechanics compared to the early 2000 verisons. The puzzles and codes are challenging enough to keep you on your toes and make you use your brain, the plot is interesting and has enough action to keep you following and excited, and just overall, a more personal story then what you're used to from these games. You find out a lot regarding Nancy's mom, Kate Drew, and her whole second life as a spy and even get to see into Nancy's past and flashbacks of her as a young child and her mother.


One issue though is regarding the Jabberwocky poem puzzle. Trying to uncode it was extremely difficult and honestly made no sense to me. If you understand it and uncode it with ease, kudos to you, but if you're like me, you'll have to resort to looking it up online for that bit. Otherwise, all the other puzzles and codes were hard enough to get me to grit through it but not so difficult that it left me clueless and no sense of direction of what to do.

review: Hands down, favorite Nancy Drew title EVER. We finally see a humanized Nancy with an emotional backstory, and the story line is SO edgy that it really keeps you engaged. I think that by the time this title was made, HERInteractive realized that many of their players skew older than originally intended, because this storyline honestly contains "thematic elements" as they call it in the movies. You really feel like a spy in this one, and I mean like an action-movie spy, not just a teenage detective. The flashbacks are awesome, it's fun to travel around Scotland, and the characters are colorful and multi-dimensional. Definitely recommended for longtime fans and newcomers alike, though I would caution parents to maybe check out the bioterrorism-type theme before you decide if you are comfortable with your 10-to-12-year-old playing this one. There are other, milder titles to try first (like Secret of the Old Clock, which was my favorite when I was young and a great first title). So much fun, though!

review:
[b]A silent spy is a dead spy[/b]

Nancy Drew is one of the most well known fictional detectives in literature. Many grew up with her books and games, and even if they forget the name, Nancy Drew can easily bring up an image of a teenage girl detective solving mysteries. For her 29th adventure in her game series, it gets a little more personal. In both her books and the games, Nancy‚Äôs mother is not looked into nor given any extensive backstory. All we know is that she died when Nancy was young. So what happens when Mrs. Drew is the mystery?

With Mrs. Drew‚Äôs bare backstory, Nancy Drew: The Silent Spy builds on it to give her more character. Named Kate Drew, she visited Glasgow, Scotland after getting a phone call eight years ago. She never returned and died in a car accident.

Eight years later, a mysterious letter is delivered to Nancy from a MI-5 organization named Cathedral asking her to go to Scotland. Kate‚Äôs death is not what it seems and has gone unsolved since. Soon learning that her mother was a spy taking down a terrorist organization called Revenant with the cost of her life. But Kate‚Äôs death is believed to have been intentionally caused by Revenant. Nancy soon finds herself taking her mother‚Äôs place as Revenant starts to rise again.

As she arrives in Scotland, it seems like the few people she meets is nice and immediately wants to help her. Each character has their own quirks that I could not help but love. Other than the repeating characters of Carson and Ned, both wanting Nancy to get home safely and giving you information this time around, there are only a few characters. There is Bridget, a friendly native that takes an instant liking to you, Moira, a woman who has a close connection with Kate, Alec, a skip tracer, and Ewan, your Cathedral contact that assists you throughout your mission. Don‚Äôt put too much trust in them, after all everyone hides secrets.

A lot of the characters are likeable, my favorite being Bridget, and you do get the feeling that they are hiding something from you. Bridget in particular gives off an energetic vibe, mostly through her great voice acting and writing. In fact, everyone is written and voice acted well. While I do not know my Scottish accents, all of the people that is supposed to have one does have a constant and natural sounding accent. None of them suddenly changes it for no reason and you can hear that they share the same accent.

The dynamic of Carson and Nancy is heartwarming. They both miss Kate, but they have different ways of showing it. While Nancy agrees to go to Scotland to learn of her mother‚Äôs true lifestyle, Carson wants Nancy to be safe. He does lock up some of Kate‚Äôs papers but it is to keep her safe as Carson knows her drive to solve mysteries. When he realizes Nancy will not go home till she finds out, they both have a heart to heart and Carson goes along with it.

With Nancy, you do see why everyone wants her to go back home. Nancy is the only one not caring about the harm that can befall her, mostly seen with Revenant contacting her. You can decide to do the activities Revenant gives you to gain more information about your mother and thus show how far she is willing to go. She also gets to do some cool spy stuff with the gadgets she gets. A few flashbacks to Nancy‚Äôs childhood when Kate was still alive is also nice. It further connects her to Kate and makes it more believable.

You get a lot of history of Scotland through books and newspapers, some optional and others used for puzzles. With one of the ways you can get money making cookies at the stand outside of your hotel. Though you only get a few areas to go to. I‚Äôm disappointed that Nancy did not go to where Kate had her car ‚Äúaccident‚Äù, especially since she went mostly for her mother, or try to dig up any reports. Most being inside, with one of the pubs not able to enter. It would of been interesting to have a lot of areas to go to branching off of the train station to give it a more of a Scottish feel rather than just locations.

There are a variety of puzzles for you to enjoy. Some puzzles go with the Scotland area such as having you figure out the names of Scottish food and recreating and recognizing a tartan design. Others use logic as you try to figure out various codes or arranging letters to unlock something. There are interesting puzzles scattered around, one of the most memorable ones contain you having to understand sheet music. Only a few puzzles are timed and they give a good amount of time in relation to what you need to do. Be careful, as most have an implied timer. You can always start over if you are caught.

Though why is Cathedral using the same passwords from eight years ago, especially when Revenant needs the information Kate has to rise again. There had to be someone in Cathedral that knew, or could of hacked into, her password just in case Revenant figured it out before Nancy.

There was one puzzle that did not work out in their favor, the Jabberwocky puzzle. Early on you find out one of the papers in your suitcase was a poem Kate kept called the Jabberwocky. Once you receive a colored version, all you know is that it is a regular poem. Though suspicion is raised with some words being colored and most not. This is when it gets muddled. Nancy Drew games are designed in a way that you can do steps out of order if possible, so you do get some wiggle room. The problem with the Jabberwocky puzzle is that you will know it is a puzzle, and not just a poem, if you skip to the last clue. Kate left a recording of her giving instructions on how to decode the message, and even Nancy says there is a message hidden in the poem, but you can not solve it yet. You have to get told to follow those instructions on a note. This could of been handled with the note not being needed to start decoding but for the player to use it as a reference, like the books you get are. I am also disappointed that you can‚Äôt find all the letters yourself, as it already writes down the letters and puts spaces where it did not specify in the recording. It would of added another way for the player to take the role of a detective.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
+ Strong story
+ Good voice work and soundtrack
+ Puzzles
+ A few easter eggs scattered around

+/- Limited locations

‚Äì Some unanswered questions
‚Äì Jabberwocky puzzle

Nancy Drew: The Silent Spy is a great game in the Nancy Drew series. It was interesting having a game where Nancy is driven by her personal need to know what happened to her mother. Everything is handled seriously and you can feel how the Drew family misses Kate. It was a risk giving Kate Drew this backstory and having the player not believing it from the other family members, but it does work out. If you have not played the others, or only played some of them like I have, this is a good entry point.
